metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: 30m month compositing vegetation index (NDVI/EVI) product of Heihe River Basin (2011-2014)
metadata.description: The 30 m / month vegetation index (NDVI / EVI) data set of Heihe River basin provides the monthly NDVI / EVI composite products from 2011 to 2014. This data uses the characteristics of HJ / CCD data of China's domestic satellite, which has both high time resolution (2 days after Networking) and spatial resolution (30 m), to construct multi angle observation data set. The average composite MC method is used as the main algorithm for synthesis, and the backup algorithm uses VI method. At the same time, the main observation angles of the multi-source data set are used as part of the quality descriptor to help analyze the angle effect of the composite vegetation index residue. The remote sensing data acquired every month can provide more angles and more observations than the single day sensor data, but the quality of multi-phase and multi angle observation data is uneven due to the difference of on orbit operation time and performance of the sensor. Therefore, in order to effectively use the multi-temporal and multi angle observation data, before using the multi-source data set to synthesize the vegetation index, the algorithm designs the data quality inspection of the multi-source data set, removing the observation with large error and inconsistent observation. The verification results in the middle reaches of Heihe River show that the NDVI / EVI composite results of the combined multi temporal and multi angle observation data are in good agreement with the ground measured data (R2 = 0.89, RMSE = 0.092). In a word, the 30 m / month NDVI / EVI data set of Heihe River Basin comprehensively uses multi temporal and multi angle observation data to improve the estimation accuracy and time resolution of parameter products, so as to realize the stable standardized products from scratch and better serve the application of remote sensing data products.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that addresses the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method that addresses this challenge is the use of hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, as implemented in the HiWATER experiment. This includes a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions, a superstation within the oasis, and various EC towers and automatic meteorological stations installed in different landscapes such as sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that utilizes multiple observation angles and times to improve the accuracy and temporal resolution of vegetation indices?
Example.Answer: An example is the dataset providing 30m/monthly NDVI/EVI composite products for the Heihe River Basin from 2011 to 2014. This dataset uses data from China's HJ/CCD satellite, employing the MC method as the main algorithm for compositing and VI method as a backup, to enhance estimation accuracy and temporal resolution of the vegetation indices.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using multi-angle observations in the creation of vegetation index datasets?
Definition.Answer: Multi-angle observations are significant in the creation of vegetation index datasets as they provide more comprehensive data by capturing different perspectives, which helps in reducing the angle effect in the synthesized vegetation index. This approach improves the estimation accuracy and time resolution of the parameter products.

Definition.Question: What are the main challenges associated with multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes?
Definition.Answer: The main challenges associated with multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes include the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders progress in understanding and scaling eco-hydrological interactions on heterogeneous surfaces. These challenges necessitate comprehensive data collection methods like those used in HiWATER, which employ instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales.

Comparison.Question: How do the data quality control measures in multiscale eco-hydrological observations compare to those used in the synthesis of vegetation indices from remote sensing data?
Comparison.Answer: In multiscale eco-hydrological observations, data quality control involves sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation, ensuring careful calibration and synchronization of diverse sensors. In contrast, for synthesizing vegetation indices from remote sensing data, quality checks focus on removing large error observations and inconsistent data to effectively utilize multi-temporal and multi-angle observations.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of multi-angle and multi-temporal data collection methods enhance the accuracy and reliability of remote sensing datasets in eco-hydrological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multi-angle and multi-temporal data collection can enhance accuracy by combining observations from multiple perspectives and times, which helps to mitigate the inconsistencies and errors associated with single-time or single-angle data. This approach allows for the construction of a more comprehensive dataset that captures the variability and dynamics of vegetation indices like NDVI/EVI, thus improving the estimation accuracy and consistency with ground truth measurements.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the deployment of hierarchically nested instrumentation scales contribute to understanding eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: Deploying hierarchically nested instrumentation scales allows researchers to capture eco-hydrological processes at various spatial and temporal scales, offering a detailed understanding of interactions within complex landscapes like oasis-desert systems. This method facilitates the collection of comprehensive datasets covering different environmental gradients and helps in understanding the variability and dynamics across scales, as demonstrated by the arrangement of instruments in different landscape settings and the coordination of intensive observation periods.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for multiscale observations in capturing eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for multiscale observations arises due to the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, which is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to establish a sparse network with hierarchically nested scales for data collection in oasis-desert interactions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is necessary to establish a sparse network with hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes effectively and to investigate the interaction between the oasis and the surrounding desert landscapes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact of integrating multiscale observations on the accuracy of eco-hydrological process modeling in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiscale observations can significantly enhance the accuracy of eco-hydrological process modeling by providing comprehensive data across different spatial and temporal scales, which addresses the challenge of data scarcity and improves parameter estimation.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to synthesize vegetation indices from multi-temporal and multi-angle observations in eco-hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Synthesizing vegetation indices from multi-temporal and multi-angle observations is crucial for improving the estimation accuracy and temporal resolution of parameter products, allowing for more effective application of remote sensing data products by addressing the variability and inconsistency in sensor data quality.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives are pursued by implementing multi-scale instrumentation in eco-hydrological experiments like the ones in the Heihe watershed?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective of implementing multi-scale instrumentation, such as eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations arranged in hierarchically nested scales, is to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and understand the interactions within heterogeneous surfaces like the oasis-desert system, overcoming challenges posed by the poor availability of multiscale observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in constructing a multiscale eco-hydrological dataset using the instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The construction of a multiscale eco-hydrological dataset involves arranging instruments in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale processes. This includes a sparse network to investigate interactions, a superstation within the oasis, and the installation of eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations in different landscapes. Intensive observations at the irrigation district scale and remote sensing missions using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers are also part of the process.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in ensuring the quality of observational data collected for eco-hydrological research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ensuring the quality of observational data involves careful quality control throughout the process, including sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. These steps are crucial to maintaining the integrity and reliability of the data for eco-hydrological research.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have facilitated the integration of multi-angle and multi-temporal observation data in improving vegetation index synthesis?
Enablement.Answer: The use of domestic satellite HJ/CCD data, which offers high temporal (2-day) and spatial (30m) resolution, enables the construction of multi-angle observation datasets. This allows for more comprehensive synthesis of vegetation indices through methods like the average composite MC algorithm, enhancing the estimation accuracy of parameter products.

Enablement.Question: How do hierarchically nested instrumentation and multiscale observations enable a better understanding of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The arrangement of instruments in hierarchically nested scales, including flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, enables the capture of multiscale eco-hydrological processes. This structure supports detailed observation and analysis of interactions in oasis-desert systems, leading to a comprehensive understanding of these processes.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies are necessary to ensure quality control and consistency in datasets collected from diverse remote sensing technologies?
Enablement.Answer: Quality control is ensured through sensor calibration, meticulous data collection, processing, and dataset generation. These methodologies are critical in managing data from technologies like LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers, guaranteeing the reliability and consistency of observations.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multi-angle and multi-temporal observations be expected to enhance the accuracy of eco-hydrological datasets in heterogeneous surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of multi-angle and multi-temporal observations is expected to enhance the accuracy by providing more comprehensive data, capturing different perspectives and conditions over time, which helps in better estimation of parameters such as vegetation indices. This approach can reduce errors and inconsistencies often found in single-time or single-angle observations, leading to improved alignment with ground-truth measurements.

Judgmental.Question: How effective is the use of multi-angle and multi-temporal observations in improving the accuracy of vegetation indices in eco-hydrological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multi-angle and multi-temporal observations is quite effective in improving the accuracy of vegetation indices, as demonstrated by the validation results in the Heihe basin. The combined NDVI/EVI synthesis from these observations showed a good match with ground measurements, with an R2 of 0.89 and an RMSE of 0.092, indicating high accuracy in eco-hydrological assessments.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could data collection methods in hierarchical scales contribute to addressing the scarcity of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Data collection methods using hierarchical scales can significantly contribute by providing comprehensive multiscale and multidisciplinary data through a structured observation network. For instance, the implementation of intensive observation periods (IOPs) and instrumentation such as eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing can effectively capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and interactions, thus addressing the scarcity of multiscale observations.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how multiscale observations are effectively collected and integrated in eco-hydrological research.
Assertion.Answer: The HiWATER experiment addresses the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations by arranging instruments on hierarchically nested scales, including a sparse network and a superstation within an oasis, to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes.

Assertion.Question: I can't grasp how multi-angle and multi-time observations improve the accuracy of vegetation indices.
Assertion.Answer: The vegetation index dataset from the Heihe River Basin utilizes multi-angle and multi-time observations to enhance estimation accuracy by reducing angle effects and integrating data quality checks to remove large errors and inconsistencies.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to capture eco-hydrological processes at multiple scales in a heterogeneous surface environment.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods in this field involve instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary data. Several intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales, and a sparse network was established to investigate oasis-desert interaction. A superstation within the oasis and multiple eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and a range of remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR and imaging spectrometers were employed to capture eco-hydrological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges encountered in the collection and utilization of multiscale observation data for ecological and hydrological research.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the main challenges is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders progress in the field of eco-hydrological research. Moreover, the quality of multiscale and multi-angle observation data is variable due to differences in sensor performance and operational periods. Ensuring high-quality data requires careful quality control, including sensor calibration, data collection, processing, and dataset generation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the types of datasets that can be generated from a multiscale eco-hydrological observation system and their potential applications.
Request/Directive.Answer: A multiscale eco-hydrological observation system can generate datasets such as flux observation matrices from eddy covariance towers, data from large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, soil moisture and leaf area index, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers. These datasets have applications in studying vegetation dynamics, photosynthesis processes, and interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems. They are available for further research at platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.
